properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A division by zero occurs.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
This example of printing usage information with formatted output shows a flaw that can be exploited to run arbitrary code. By controlling the content of the format string a user can, in effect, cotrol execution of the formatted output function.
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 204, Figure 6-1

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A pointer to a local variable will go out of scope after the return.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

message.text: Return of Pointer Value Outside of Expected Range.

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
Incorrect pointer arithmetic to access a data structure.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

taxa.name: Return of Pointer Value Outside of Expected Range

message.text: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow').

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
Get password program. The security flaw is due to the gets() on line 25. If the entry contains more than 11 characters (remember the null terminating character) the gets() function performs a buffer overflow.
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 33, Figure 2-9

taxa.name: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')

properties.author: SecureSoftware
properties.description:
When an exception is thrown and not caught, the process has given up an
opportunity to decide if a given failure or event is worth a change in execution. (from TCCLASP-5_6_18_10)

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A non null-terminated string is read.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description: Extremly insecure stdio implementation. The program reads a filename from stdin on line 26 and attemps to open the file on line 26. This program is vulnerable to buffer overflows on line 26 and format string exploit on line 30. From  \"Secure Coding in C and C  \" by Robert C. Seacord. Page 215, Figure 6-8

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
Use of negative index when accessing an array or negative size when creating it.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

message.text: Free of Memory not on the Heap.

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
free() is given a pointer to something else than an allocated memory block.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

taxa.name: Free of Memory not on the Heap

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A signed integer looses its sign when implicitly casted to an unsigned integer.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

properties.description:
Reading of an uninitialized variable.

Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

properties.description:
An array is overrun.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

message.text: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime.

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A C++ array is not deleted correctly, which could lead to memory leaks.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

properties.description:
A reference to an allocated resource is lost because of pointer reuse.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

taxa.name: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime

message.text: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow').

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
Extracting characters from cin into character array. The operator>> will copy outside the bound of the statically allocated array if the length of the input is more than 11 characters.
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 29, Figure 2-4

taxa.name: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')

message.text: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime.

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A non-virtual destructor is never called.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

taxa.name: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime

message.text: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer.

properties.author: SecureSoftware
properties.description:
A buffer underwrite condition occurs when a buffer is indexed with a negative
number, or pointer arithmetic with a negative value results in a position before
the beginning of the valid memory location. (from TCCLASP-5_2_5_9)

taxa.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

message.text: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer.

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
Defective string manipulation code. If the first argument exceeds 128 characters (including the null one) the program will write outside of the bounds of the fixed size array. 
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 32, Figure 2-8

taxa.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
An erased c++ iterator is dereferenced.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

message.text: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow').

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
Use of gets(), strcpy() and similar functions, where there is no way to limit the size of the read string (no destination size parameter).
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

taxa.name: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')

message.text: Loop with Unreachable Exit Condition ('Infinite Loop').

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
The condition to exit the loop is never satisfied.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

taxa.name: Loop with Unreachable Exit Condition ('Infinite Loop')

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A pointer to allocated memory is used, even if the memory block was freed before (the pointer was passed to free()).
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

message.text: Use of sizeof() on a Pointer Type.

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
The size passed to malloc is not big enough to represent the type.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

taxa.name: Use of sizeof() on a Pointer Type

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A past-the-end c++ iterator is dereferenced.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description: Code with TOCTOU - Time of check, Time of use - culnerability involving stat(). The TOCTOU check occurs with the call of stat() on line 41 and the use is the call of fopen() on line 49. An attacker can simply exploit this vulnerabilty using a symlink: erase the file and make a symbolic link to this name and the attacker_file.From \'Secure Coding in C and C  \' by Robert C. Seacord.Page 225, Figure 7-4

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
Modifying the instruction pointer. The invocation through the function pointer funcPtr uses an indirect reference, and the address inthe referenced location can be overwritten. As the function pointer address cannot be resolved at compiled time, it can be exploited to transfer control to arbitrary code.
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 81, Figure 3-4

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
Common off-by-one defect. The strcpy() copies 11 characters in the source buffer including the terminating null character. Due to the index value, the assignment on line 31 cause an out-of-bound.
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 30, Figure 2-6

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A null pointer is dereferenced.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
Because of the test for file existence in lines 33 and 35 and the file open on line 36 both use file names. This code contains a TOCTOU - Time of check, Time of use - vulnerability. The code can be exploited by the creation of a symbolic link with the name of the file.
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 258, Figure 7-5

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
The value exceeds the representation capacity of the type.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A value is casted into a type that can't represent it, because it's too small.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
Buffer overflow if the input is not validated. Every operation may write outside the bound of the statically allocated character array. 
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 28, Figure 2-2

message.text: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer.

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
Exploit of buffer overflow in dynamic memory on Windows. This exploit requires that the overwriten memory adress is executable.
The HeapFree() on line 38 creates a gap in the contiguous allocated memory. The memcpy() on line 39 is an example of exploit. The first 16 bytes of malArg overwrite the user data area, the next 8 bytes overwrite the boundary tag for the free chunk and the next 8 bytes of malArg overwrite the pointers to the next and previous chunck.
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 128, Figure 4-29

taxa.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

message.text: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer.

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A buffer function is called with a destination size too big.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

taxa.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

message.text: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer.

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
memcopy() is used to copy memory from one region to another, but the two regions overlap, which is not supported by memcopy(). NOTE: the implementation in vstudio seems to handle overlapping regions correctly, even if the doc says otherwise.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 1518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

taxa.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
The bit shift is bigger than the size of the integral type or is negative.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

properties.author: Secure Software
properties.description: Test of tool ability to identify an unchecked error condition.

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
Null-termination defect. There is no place allocated for the null terminating character. Thereby, the strcpy() writes beyond the character array.
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 31, Figure 2-7

message.text: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Output Used by a Downstream Component ('Injection').

properties.author: Robert C. Seacord
properties.description:
Program vulnerable to arc injection exploit. The buffer overflow occurs on line 25 when memcpy() will copy the first entry argument into the 3 characters array.
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 49, Figure 2-27

taxa.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Output Used by a Downstream Component ('Injection')

properties.author: DRDC
properties.description:
A string function is passed a value without format string. This can lead to a format string vulnerability if the value can be in control of a malicious user.
These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
Please see test case ID 000-001-518 for an executable suite of all the DRDC test cases.

message.text: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer.

properties.description:
Buffer overflow by gets() if input is more than 80 characters.
From "Secure Coding in C and C++" by Robert C. Seacord.
Page 27, Figure 2-1

These test cases were graciously provided by Frederic Michaud of Defense Research & Development Canada - Valcartier.
